answers.author: Maya Williams
answers.text:
I just did a survey on this and got back responses from 18 jurisdictions.  I will attach our memo to our Council and the spreadsheet of responses.

[We] surveyed several cities to find out whether jurisdictions are using a paperless agenda process and whether the paperless process resulted in lower costs and/or less staff time spent assembling paperless packets.
We found that a good number of jurisdictions (9 of 18) are issuing laptops, ipads, or sending agendas through email and saving to CDs.  A couple require council/board members to download from the jurisdiction's website.  Almost none of them continue to send hard copies of their agendas to staff. Of those jurisdictions that have not gone paperless, they leave it to the discretion of their councils/boards to decide whether they receive hard copies, download it themselves, or have them emailed.
The City distributes 55 copies of the Council agenda packet internally and 45 are left over for the public (100 total).  We distribute 62 copies of the RDA packet internally and 15 copies are left over for the public (77 total). 
We noted that there is not a significant reduction in the amount of staff time used for uploading information to electronic devices or emailing.  However, there is and can be a significant reduction in staff time for sending copies of agendas and attachments to internal staff.  For example, [staff] spends about 1.5 work days per week coordinating and organizing the 19 sets of hard copy enclosures that the City distributes weekly.
Additionally, there is a great deal of cost reductions associated with no longer sending copies of agendas to City staff.  For example, in July 2010, the average number of pages for the agenda packets was 45.  The total costs we incurred for the month was $869.50 divided by 4 weeks equals $217.38 per week.  Over a 6 months month period, the total is about $5,200. The $5,200 total does not include the 5 hard copies of the agenda packet we make in-house for Council, the costs for the 19 sets of enclosures, or the RDA packets.
The 19 sets of enclosures are produced by each department who is responsible for the staff report(s).  At a cost of about $.0055 per page, we estimate that enclosures cost a minimum of $0.55/set, $10.45/week, or $271.70 over 6 months.  On the high end, photocopying enclosures can cost upwards of $2.75/set, or $52.25/week.  The number of pages for the enclosures vary, but can range from 100 to over 500 per week.
While some jurisdictions indicated that iPads paid for themselves within a year, we estimate the City would easily recoup the cost of purchasing five (5) iPads for Council use within 6 months.
It is undetermined how much ITS time would be required to maintain ipads, laptops, and similar technologies.
#


I just did a survey on this and got back responses from 18 jurisdictions.  I will attach our memo to our Council and the spreadsheet of responses.



[We] surveyed several cities to find out whether jurisdictions are using a paperless agenda process and whether the paperless process resulted in lower costs and/or less staff time spent assembling paperless packets.

We found that a good number of jurisdictions (9 of 18) are issuing laptops, ipads, or sending agendas through email and saving to CDs.  A couple require council/board members to download from the jurisdiction's website.  Almost none of them continue to send hard copies of their agendas to staff. Of those jurisdictions that have not gone paperless, they leave it to the discretion of their councils/boards to decide whether they receive hard copies, download it themselves, or have them emailed.

The City distributes 55 copies of the Council agenda packet internally and 45 are left over for the public (100 total).  We distribute 62 copies of the RDA packet internally and 15 copies are left over for the public (77 total). 

We noted that there is not a significant reduction in the amount of staff time used for uploading information to electronic devices or emailing.  However, there is and can be a significant reduction in staff time for sending copies of agendas and attachments to internal staff.  For example, [staff] spends about 1.5 work days per week coordinating and organizing the 19 sets of hard copy enclosures that the City distributes weekly.

Additionally, there is a great deal of cost reductions associated with no longer sending copies of agendas to City staff.  For example, in July 2010, the average number of pages for the agenda packets was 45.  The total costs we incurred for the month was $869.50 divided by 4 weeks equals $217.38 per week.  Over a 6 months month period, the total is about $5,200. The $5,200 total does not include the 5 hard copies of the agenda packet we make in-house for Council, the costs for the 19 sets of enclosures, or the RDA packets.

The 19 sets of enclosures are produced by each department who is responsible for the staff report(s).  At a cost of about $.0055 per page, we estimate that enclosures cost a minimum of $0.55/set, $10.45/week, or $271.70 over 6 months.  On the high end, photocopying enclosures can cost upwards of $2.75/set, or $52.25/week.  The number of pages for the enclosures vary, but can range from 100 to over 500 per week.

While some jurisdictions indicated that iPads paid for themselves within a year, we estimate the City would easily recoup the cost of purchasing five (5) iPads for Council use within 6 months.

It is undetermined how much ITS time would be required to maintain ipads, laptops, and similar technologies.

#

answers.author: Jackson Tuttle
answers.text:
Williamsburg issued iPads to City Council members last month.  We have stopped printing Council agendas and packages.  We have already saved $811 in the first two months in copy costs (some fat agenda packages not printed!).  So far, Council is happy with it, public and press reaction OK.  Before Council authorized going ahead with it, our IT director presented a video he shot in his office (nice view of his trash can) to show how it would work.  That's posted on youtube.  Here's the link: http://www.youtube.com/Williamsburggov#p/u/0/wJbgTbxbW58

We have already saved $811 in the first two months in copy costs (some fat agenda packages not printed!).  So far, Council is happy with it, public and press reaction OK.  Before Council authorized going ahead with it, our IT director presented a video he shot in his office (nice view of his trash can) to show how it would work.  That's posted on youtube.  Here's the link: http://www.youtube.com/Williamsburggov#p/u/0/wJbgTbxbW58

Cancel

answers.author: Robert Wherry
answers.text:
We implemented a paperless agenda.  Three of the Commissioners use iPads, two laptops.  The city issues the iPads, laptops are provided by the Commissioner if they opt out of an iPad.  We are also extending this program to all other appointed Boards and Commissions.  
IPads will also be assigned to staff members in lieu of a printed agenda.
The agenda and attachments etc. are posted on the web site so they can be reviewed from any computer.  The agendas work best if they are accessed directly during the meeting rather than downloaded.
We expect the iPads/paperless agenda program to pay for itself within six months, although these are rough estimates of staff time, delivering agendas, copying, paper etc.  The Board of Commissioners really went into the program as being more efficient and flexible and avoid wasting natural resources.  It also insures all agenda and back up documents are available to the public.
The City empphasizes we will always provide a printed agenda upon request.


We implemented a paperless agenda.  Three of the Commissioners use iPads, two laptops.  The city issues the iPads, laptops are provided by the Commissioner if they opt out of an iPad.  We are also extending this program to all other appointed Boards and Commissions.  

IPads will also be assigned to staff members in lieu of a printed agenda.

The agenda and attachments etc. are posted on the web site so they can be reviewed from any computer.  The agendas work best if they are accessed directly during the meeting rather than downloaded.

We expect the iPads/paperless agenda program to pay for itself within six months, although these are rough estimates of staff time, delivering agendas, copying, paper etc.  The Board of Commissioners really went into the program as being more efficient and flexible and avoid wasting natural resources.  It also insures all agenda and back up documents are available to the public.

The City empphasizes we will always provide a printed agenda upon request.

Toni, I recently did some work with the Public Library Innovations group.  One library is now loaning out iPads in addition to the Kindles they have been loaning out for a few years.  I hope a few librarians weigh in on this question.

answers.author: Karen Windon
answers.text:
We are in a pilot phase with the iPads. Several IT staff and the County Administrators Office are testing the functionality with the goal of eliminating notebook computers in favor of the iPads. We have are able to access email through our private wifi network, or through public wireless with a VPN. We utilize LotusNotes as opposed to Outlook and the Traveler version of Lotus has worked well (with some calendar issues). Each user has found apps that work well for individual use, and docstogo is working for document syncing. They are very intuitive so training has not been an issue. Some of the work arounds for the lack of USB etc seem to be effective pending the next releases... Stay tuned!


We are in a pilot phase with the iPads. Several IT staff and the County Administrators Office are testing the functionality with the goal of eliminating notebook computers in favor of the iPads. We have are able to access email through our private wifi network, or through public wireless with a VPN. We utilize LotusNotes as opposed to Outlook and the Traveler version of Lotus has worked well (with some calendar issues). Each user has found apps that work well for individual use, and docstogo is working for document syncing. They are very intuitive so training has not been an issue. Some of the work arounds for the lack of USB etc seem to be effective pending the next releases... Stay tuned!

answers.author: Claude Larouche
answers.text:
So far...we're not using ipads.  We've had some inquiries, but so far, the limited download-upload capability has caused the inquirers to go to a light laptop instead.

answers.author: James Ley
answers.text:
Toni, we have a fully automated agenda development process - that is until it came time to produce the agenda book for the Commission.  The notebooks and laptops that we tried in th epast simply did not lend themselves to easy scrolling and the tools for annotation required too many processes.  We spend $5000 for every meeting to reproduce books from an electronic system.
I now have three BCC members using Ipads for this purpose and so far so good.  Contact Robin Focht rfocht@scgov.net


Toni, we have a fully automated agenda development process - that is until it came time to produce the agenda book for the Commission.  The notebooks and laptops that we tried in th epast simply did not lend themselves to easy scrolling and the tools for annotation required too many processes.  We spend $5000 for every meeting to reproduce books from an electronic system.

I now have three BCC members using Ipads for this purpose and so far so good.  Contact Robin Focht rfocht@scgov.net

answers.author: Mark Abeles-Allison
answers.text:
Are there any counties that have gone the iPad route?  It seems like the county committee structure would lend itself even better to an electronic agenda.


Are there any counties that have gone the iPad route?  It seems like the county committee structure would lend itself even better to an electronic agenda.

answers.author: James Lenner
answers.text:
The Village of Johnstown is currently looking into a paperless agenda and supporting documents. We are also working with a document management company to backscan all relavent documents so that they may be available to Council members. We will be looking into a paperless administration office within three years. The first phase of this program will involve the paperless applications and inspections for the planning department. It will then phase into the water and sewer department and last the finance department.

We are also working with a document management company to backscan all relavent documents so that they may be available to Council members. We will be looking into a paperless administration office within three years. The first phase of this program will involve the paperless applications and inspections for the planning department. It will then phase into the water and sewer department and last the finance department.

answers.author: Patricia Leary
answers.text:
Yolo County, CA began using a paperless agenda system and IPads earlier this year.  Estimated annual net cost savings were approximately $35,000.  The transition was surprisingly smooth and fully implemented within a very short time.


Yolo County, CA began using a paperless agenda system and IPads earlier this year.  Estimated annual net cost savings were approximately $35,000.  The transition was surprisingly smooth and fully implemented within a very short time.

answers.author: Kerry Goode
answers.text:
City of Durham has began a City-wide ipad pilot to understand how to effectively align the new technology to the business units. Departments will pilot several applications. Examples are: Council agenda paperless process,  
inspections field application, replacement of laptops and many others. Hopefully, once the pilot is complete, there will be a much better understanding of how iPad can bring value throughout the City.


City of Durham has began a City-wide ipad pilot to understand how to effectively align the new technology to the business units. Departments will pilot several applications. Examples are: Council agenda paperless process,  
inspections field application, replacement of laptops and many others. Hopefully, once the pilot is complete, there will be a much better understanding of how iPad can bring value throughout the City.

author: Toni Shope
text:
The Alliance for Innovation is exploring the use of iPads by Local Government.  Please share how you are using, who is using, version using 3G or wifi, applications using for local government purposes, print cost saving estimates, training, and other relevant information. 
Thank you for your response!
title: Use of iPads by Local Government
